claim: Very few films are still illegal to show in France.

supporting.text: France has strict but clear censorship laws that primarily target extreme content, making most films legally permissible.

attacks.text: France has strict but clear censorship laws that primarily target extreme content, making most films legally permissible.
France has banned numerous films historically, including some that are not extreme, such as those deemed to incite violence or hatred.
Many of the historically banned films have since been re-evaluated and are now legally available, showing that France's censorship is not permanent for most cases.
Certain films, such as those depicting real criminal acts or terrorism, remain illegal to show in France regardless of artistic merit.
The number of films that remain banned for non-extreme reasons is statistically negligible compared to the vast majority of films that are legally permissible.

supporting.text: The French legal system allows for the classification and restriction of films rather than outright bans, reducing the number of illegal films.

attacks.text: The French legal system allows for the classification and restriction of films rather than outright bans, reducing the number of illegal films.

Historical films banned decades ago remain technically illegal, even if no longer actively enforced.
Legal reforms and cultural shifts have led to the re-evaluation and unbanning of many historically prohibited films.

supporting.text: Historical bans on films in France have been largely overturned or are no longer enforced, leaving very few films currently illegal.

attacks.text: Historical bans on films in France have been largely overturned or are no longer enforced, leaving very few films currently illegal.

supporting.text: International agreements and EU laws promote freedom of expression, limiting the grounds on which France can ban films.

attacks.text: International agreements and EU laws promote freedom of expression, limiting the grounds on which France can ban films.

EU law supersedes national law in many areas, and France has been compelled to align its policies with EU directives on freedom of expression.
Even under EU law, member states can invoke exceptions for public order, health, or morals, allowing France to maintain some film bans.

supporting.text: The French government provides a legal framework for film distribution that includes age ratings and content warnings instead of outright bans.

attacks.text: The French government provides a legal framework for film distribution that includes age ratings and content warnings instead of outright bans.

supporting.text: Public and legal challenges to film bans in France have led to a significant reduction in the number of films that remain illegal.

attacks.text: Public and legal challenges to film bans in France have led to a significant reduction in the number of films that remain illegal.
